Award.AwardTitle: The p-Adic Langlands Program and Related Topics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The conference "The p-adic Langlands Program and Related Topics" will be held May 16-20, 2016 at Indiana University Bloomington. The main theme of the conference is the interplay between number theory and group theory, as envisioned by Robert Langlands and known as the Langlands Program. The conference will be devoted to a recently developed branch of the Langlands program that has close ties with the spectacular solution of Fermat's Last Theorem by A. Wiles. One scientific aim of the conference is to provide a roadmap of the current avenues of research in this rapidly developing field that will serve as a guide to this area for the mathematical community, in particular graduate students and young researchers. The main activity of the conference will be twenty-three lectures by leading experts from the United States and overseas that will be videotaped and made freely available on the conference website http://pages.iu.edu/~mstrauch/conference_2016/. An important purpose of the conference is to foster communication and collaboration. In particular, the organizers will publish the conference proceedings, with research articles as well as introductory surveys.

The p-adic Langlands correspondence seeks to relate p-adic Galois representations to Banach space representations of p-adic reductive groups. The fundamental work of Pierre Colmez in the case of two-dimensional Galois representations has confirmed the expectation that such a correspondence should exist. The current focus of research is on higher-dimensional representations and on base fields other than the field of p-adic numbers. Important progress in closely related areas has recently been made, namely in the study of eigenvarieties, deformations of Galois representations, p-adic Hodge Theory, modular representations of p-adic groups, and geometric realizations of Langlands correspondences. The conference will bring together experts who have made substantial contributions in each of these areas and thereby pave the way for new insights.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project outcomes report concerns the conference award "The p-adic Langlands Program and Related Topics".

(1) Organizational aspects. The conference was organized by the PI together with co-organizer Dr. Keenan J. Kidwell (who was at the time of the conference a postdoctoral fellow at the PI's home institution, the Department of Mathematics of Indiana University Bloomington).

The conference took place May 16-20, 2016, on the campus of Indiana University. The conference was announced via the PI's home page (http://pages.iu.edu/~mstrauch/conference_2016/), via e-mails to leading researchers in their fields, and via the conference poster which was sent to about 150 universities and research institutions, located mainly in the United States but also overseas. (See the accompanying image of the conference poster.)

The total number of participants was about 90, among those 22 speakers, 65 non-speaker participants from other universities, most of those being advanced graduate students or postdocs, and about 5-8 local participants from Indiana University Bloomington.

(2) Purpose and Topics. The purpose of the conference was to bring together experts working in the p-adic Langlands program and related areas, and to provide an overview of current research pursued in fields like: representations of p-adic reductive groups in characteristic p, p-adic Banach space representations and locally analytic representations, p-adic Galois representations and their deformation spaces, p-adic Hodge Theory, (phi,Gamma)-modules, eigenvarieties, and p-adic automorphic forms.

The Langlands program aims at exhibiting and explaining links between various kinds of symmetries in geometry and number theory.

There were 22 one-hour presentations, 10 from speakers working at universities in the United States and 12 from speakers based at institutions abroad.

In addition to those talks there was a poster session in the afternoon on May 18, 2017, during which about 10 junior participants presented posters.

(3) Names of speakers, their affiliation at the time of the conference, and titles of their talks.

 1. Noriyuki Abe (Hokkaido University): On the structure of modulo p compact induction of p-adic groups.

2. Rebecca Bellovin (Imperial College London): Local epsilon-isomorphisms in families.

3. John Bergdall (Boston University): Slopes of modular forms and the ghost series.

4. Laurent Berger (ENS de Lyon): Iwasawa theory of F-analytic representations.

5. Bryden Cais (University of Arizona): Differentials on the modular tower and representations of GL(2) (mod p).

6. Ana Caraiani (Princeton University): Patching and p-adic local Langlands  for GL(2,Qp).

7. Yiwen Ding (Imperial College London): Companion points and locally analytic socle for GL(2,L).

8. Gabriel Dospinescu (ENS de Lyon): Locally analytic functions on the Drinfeld tower.

9. Elmar Grosse-Kloenne (Humbold University Berlin): Modular Hecke modules and Lubin-Tate (phi,Gamma)-modules.

10. David Hansen (Columbia University): Critical p-adic L-functions for Hilbert modular forms.

11. Eugen Hellmann (University of Bonn): Towards a Breuil-Mezard type conjecture for locally analytic principle series representations.

12. Florian Herzig (University of Toronto): On the mod p and p-adic Langlands program for GL(n)

13. Kiran Kedlaya (UC San Diego): Multivariate Robba rings and Frobenius modules.

14. Erick Knight (Harvard University): A p-adic Jacquet-Langlands Correspondence.

15. Daniel Le (University of Toronto): Potentially crystalline deformation rings and applications to p-adic local-global compatibility.

16. Tong Liu (Purdue University): Crystalline lift and overconvergence of p-adic Galois representations.

17. Judith Ludwig (University of Bonn): p-adic automorphic forms and endoscopy.

18. James Newton (Imperial College London): Extended eigenvarieties for overconvergent cohomology.

19. David Savitt (Johns Hopkins University): Moduli stacks of potentially Barsotti-Tate Galois representations.

20. Peter Schneider (University of Muenster): The derived pro-p Iwahori-Hecke algebra of SL(2,F)

21. Claus Sorensen (UC San Diego): Deformation rings and parabolic induction.

22. Liang Xiao (University of Connecticut): On the ghost conjecture of Bergdall and Pollack.

(4) Documentation. With the exception of one talk, all talks have been professionally video recorded and are available via the PI's home page ((http://pages.iu.edu/~mstrauch/conference_2016/videos/).

(5) Concluding remarks. Several participants expressed their opinion to the PI,either during the conference or afterwards, that the conference was a very productive event regarding the exchange of current ideas in the area of the p-adic Langlands Program. There were many lively discussions among participants during breaks and during the poster session. In summary it can be said that the conference provided a very welcome place for all participants, but in particular for the many junior participants, to learn about this exciting and rapidly developing field.
